Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Comparing Tibetan Macaque (Macaca Thibetana) Daytime and Nighttime Social Behaviors
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine and compare the daytime and nighttime social dynamics of a group of free-ranging, provisioned Tibetan macaques (Macaca thibetana) at the Valley of the Wild Monkeys, Mt. Huangshan, Anhui, China. Ongoing research on these wild, but habituated (used to human presence), macaques has been conducted since 1986. The macaques' social behaviors will be observed and recorded at their nightly sleeping sites using camera traps and at their daily feeding sites using standard behavioral observation procedures. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Jin-Hua Li and Dr. Dongpo Xia of Anhui University who are experts on the Tibetan macaques at Mt. Huangshan. This project will help fill a substantial gap in the primatological literature: the vast majority focuses on daytime behaviors and neglects nighttime behaviors, which include half of a primate's lifespan. Understanding how daily cycles influence macaque social behavior may improve our understanding of our own social tendencies.

Understanding nighttime behaviors of diurnal primates provide crucial information on the full spectrum of sociality and adaptations to group living. For the first time, this project will compare the day and nighttime social behaviors of a group of free-ranging, provisioned, Tibetan macaques (Macaca thibetana) at the Valley of the Wild Monkeys, Mt. Huangshan, Anhui, China. Behavioral data will be collected using scan sampling at the daytime provisioning site and camera traps at the sleeping sites. After collection, a comparative analysis of social behaviors at the feeding and sleeping sites will provide a comprehensive depiction of this species social dynamics. Documenting behaviors at and around sleeping sites is essential for understanding the full behavioral repertoire of Tibetan macaques. This project will be the first to document the nighttime activity pattern of macaques and will influence how future studies consider primate sociality.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Camera traps are image capturing devices that are deployed and remotely triggered by an infrared motion sensor.  They are often used to record the presence, location, and time of passing fauna as a video or still photograph (Meek et al. 2015).  Camera traps are increasingly used by researchers in the field to collect ecological, spatial, temporal, and behavioral data from a variety of wildlife species (Trolliet et al. 2014; Cutler et al., 1999; Long et al., 2008; Kucera and Barrett, 2011; O’Connell et al., 2011; Swann et al. 2011; Rovero et al., 2013; Meek et al. 2015), especially large vertebrate populations, including, but not limited to tigers (Panthera tigris), chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes), and North American deer (Odocoileus spp.).  Although camera trapping eliminates many logistical complications associated with direct observations of cryptic or difficult to follow species (e.g., low visibility, observer safety, observer exhaustion, and location inaccessibility) (Anderson, 1998; Long et al., 2008 [from open camera trap metadata standard]), camera traps have limits as a survey tool and cannot fully replace other wildlife survey methods (Meek et al. 2015, Burton et al., 2015 In Forrester et al 2016).

 With the appropriate distribution of camera traps, a large collection of accessible and reusable ecological data can be generated. Using camera traps, disciplines that survey and study wildlife are rapidly moving into the “realm” of “big data”, massive amounts of data that typical data tools and practices cannot process or handle efficiently (Hampton et al. 2013), and data repositories are essential for managing and storing the large amounts of data for analysis (Forrester, 2016). As we continue to refine these technological tools that improve the management and accessibility of video data, we are challenged by the ethical dilemma of intellectual property rights and data sharing (Reichman, 2011). I address these issues in the Duan Wei Hou Project by monitoring viewership using digital analytical software (Google Analytics) and working with researchers to implement strict copyright and co-authorship policies.

In this project, I provide detailed procedures for the proper and most efficient deployment of field cameras. Using nine camera traps, I collected 5760 videos of Tibetan macaques (Macaca thibetana) from June 20 to August 1, 2018 at Mt. Huangshan, Anhui, China. All the videos collected were reviewed to ensure they captured a Tibetan macaque and then archived in a local data repository (MediaAMP). All videos are linked to Central Washington University’s (CWU) library, where students can request access and use search keywords to find videos for their research. By creating a localized data repository, I aim to resolve any and all video management shortcomings faster than larger central data repositories. Once refined, I will pursue expanding the repository so the broader primatological community can reuse the videos I collected in effort to facilitate long-term, cross-institutional research projects, and share long-term data in innovative collaborative projects.

 


Last Modified: 04/16/2018
Modified by: Kyle Runzel
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Camera traps are image capturing devices that are deployed and remotely triggered by an infrared motion sensor. They are often used to record the presence, location, and time of passing fauna as a video or still photograph (Meek et al. 2015). Camera traps are increasingly used by researchers in the field to collect ecological, spatial, temporal, and behavioral data from a variety of wildlife species (Trolliet et al. 2014; Cutler et al., 1999; Long et al., 2008; Kucera and Barrett, 2011; O?Connell et al., 2011; Swann et al. 2011; Rovero et al., 2013; Meek et al. 2015), especially large vertebrate populations, including, but not limited to tigers (Panthera tigris), chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes), and North American deer (Odocoileus spp.). Although camera trapping eliminates many logistical complications associated with direct observations of cryptic or difficult to follow species (e.g., low visibility, observer safety, observer exhaustion, and location inaccessibility) (Anderson, 1998; Long et al., 2008 [from open camera trap metadata standard]), camera traps have limits as a survey tool and cannot fully replace other wildlife survey methods (Meek et al. 2015, Burton et al., 2015 In Forrester et al 2016). With the appropriate distribution of camera traps, a large collection of accessible and reusable ecological data can be generated. Using camera traps, disciplines that survey and study wildlife are rapidly moving into the "realm" of "big data", massive amounts of data that typical data tools and practices cannot process or handle efficiently (Hampton et al. 2013), and data repositories are essential for managing and storing the large amounts of data for analysis (Forrester, 2016). As we continue to refine these technological tools that improve the management and accessibility of video data, we are challenged by the ethical dilemma of intellectual property rights and data sharing (Reichman, 2011). I address these issues in the Duan Wei Hou Project by monitoring viewership using digital analytical software (Google Analytics) and working with researchers to implement strict copyright and co-authorship policies. In this project, I provide detailed procedures for the proper and most efficient deployment of field cameras. Using nine camera traps, I collected 5760 videos of Tibetan macaques (Macaca thibetana) from June 20 to August 1, 2018 at Mt. Huangshan, Anhui, China. All the videos collected were reviewed to ensure they captured a Tibetan macaque and then archived in a local data repository (MediaAMP). All videos are linked to Central Washington University?s (CWU) library, where students can request access and use search keywords to find videos for their research. By creating a localized data repository, I aim to resolve any and all video management shortcomings faster than larger central data repositories. Once refined, I will pursue expanding the repository so the broader primatological community can reuse the videos I collected in effort to facilitate long-term, cross-institutional research projects, and share long-term data in innovative collaborative projects.
